ImageData.LabelName: Stage IIA Adenocarcinoma of the Esophagus

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Added leader line to the Esophagus label

Separated the brackets around the mucosa layer and thin muscle layer; and removed the bottom part of cancer spot in the thick muscle layer so that it just extends about ¼ inch below the white dividing line between the two main thick muscle layers
Revisions made to image per AJCC 8th edition staging

Changed brackets to curly brackets with the label line pointing to the middle of the bracket; added label for Submucosa, pointing to the white band near the top, and made the mucosa layer just include the layers from the top of the submucosa to the top of the image; and made the connective tissue layer at the very bottom a little thicker.
Removed the (1) from the title; Took off the bottom of the cancer spot so it doesn't extend quite so far into the muscle layer

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Stage IIA adenocarcinoma of the esophagus; drawing shows the esophagus and stomach. An inset shows cancer cells in the mucosa layer, thin muscle layer, submucosa layer, and thick muscle layer of the esophagus wall. The cancer cells are grade 3 or the grade is not known. Also shown is the connective tissue layer of the esophagus wall and the lymph nodes.

Stage IIA adenocarcinoma of the esophagus; drawing shows the esophagus and stomach. An inset shows cancer cells in the mucosa layer, thin muscle layer, submucosa layer, and thick muscle layer of the esophagus wall. The cancer cells are grade 3 or the grade is not known. Also shown is the connective tissue layer of the esophagus wall and the lymph nodes.

Captions.MediaCaption: Stage IIA adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. Cancer has spread into the thick muscle layer of the esophagus wall. The cancer cells are grade 3 or the grade is not known. Grade 3 cancer cells look more abnormal under a microscope and grow and spread more quickly than grade 1 and 2 cancer cells.

Stage IIA adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. Cancer has spread into the thick muscle layer of the esophagus wall. The cancer cells are grade 3 or the grade is not known. Grade 3 cancer cells look more abnormal under a microscope and grow and spread more quickly than grade 1 and 2 cancer cells.
